Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: ## Reviewing event logs  - Found key activities in the process flow from the event log.  - Identified main stages: Order Received, Material Sourcing, Quality Screening, Assembly, and In-line Quality Check.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: ## Reviewing event logs  - Identified additional activities: Testing, Re-Testing, Packaging, Labeling, Distribution Planning, and Dispatch.  - Noted Labeling may be skipped in some cases.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: ## Examining process flow  - Observed the process begins with Order Received, followed by Material Sourcing and Quality Screening.  - Found a loop between Assembly and In-line Quality Check: Assembly is done, then checked; if it fails, repeat Assembly, else proceed.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: ## Analyzing case examples  - Case 1 shows Assembly, In-line Quality Check loop, then Testing, Re-Testing loop, Packaging, Labeling, Distribution Planning, and Dispatch.  - Case 3 also shows multiple loops between Assembly and In-line Quality Check before proceeding similarly.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: ## Exploring loop structures  - Described loops using a model: *(A, B) means execute A, then either exit or execute B and repeat A.  - Confirmed Testing may loop with Re-Testing: if Testing fails, Re-Test, then back to Testing until passed.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: ## Examining process flow  - Found that after Quality Screening, the process can either proceed directly to Assembly or enter an optional loop with In-line Quality Check.  - Confirmed Assembly always occurs at least once, but the loop with In-line Quality Check may be skipped, as seen in Case 4.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - IND
Text: ## Analyzing case variations  - Case 2 includes In-line Quality Check with multiple Assembly loops, while Case 4 skips In-line Quality Check entirely.  - Noted Case 2 lacks Labeling, and Case 4 includes it, showing variability in later stages like Packaging and beyond.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: ## Modeling process choices  - Confirmed after Quality Screening, the process can choose between a simple Assembly or a loop with In-line Quality Check, as seen in Case 4.  - Noted Assembly occurs at least once, with the loop optional: if no loop, proceed directly to Testing.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: ## Analyzing loop mechanics  - Defined loops using *(A, B): execute A, then either exit or execute B and repeat A, ensuring A happens at least once.  - Observed the Testing and Re-Testing loop follows this pattern: Testing occurs, then either passes or loops back with Re-Testing.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: ## Reviewing process sequencing  - Found Packaging is always followed by an optional Labeling step, then Distribution Planning and Dispatch in sequence.  - Noted no evidence of concurrent activities; the process appears fully sequential based on the logs.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: ## Defining process transitions  - Using abbreviations like OR, MS, and QS to represent process steps, likely standing for Order, Material Sourcing, and Quality Screening.  - Modeling each step as a Transition, such as OR = Transition(OR), to define the flow in a structured format.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: ## Structuring post-Quality Screening choices  - After Quality Screening, the process can either proceed with a single Assembly (AS) or enter a loop with Assembly and In-line Quality Check (IQC).  - The loop structure, *(AS, IQC), means executing AS first, then optionally repeating AS after IQC, matching cases with multiple Assembly steps.
